items.title: Bournemouth v Arsenal: Premier League ‚Äì live
items.summary: ‚öΩ Premier League updates from the 5.30pm GMT kick-off ‚öΩ Live scores | Tables | Follow us on Bluesky | Email Barry Elsewhere in the Premier League: Wolves have finally won their first match of the season, scoring three without reply against sorry West Ham at Molineux. In news to make those of us who remember his Leeds United debut as a 16-year-old feel truly ancient, James Milner celebrated his 40th birthday by helping Brighton to a 2-0 win over Burnley, while Aston Villa got back to winning ways by beating Nottingham Forest 3-1 at Villa Park in today‚Äôs early kick-off. Wolves remain 12 points adrift of safety at the bottom of the table but today‚Äôs results mean life is looking a lot less bleak for Rob Edwards‚Äô side now than it did first thing this morning. items.title: John McGinn double sinks Forest and provides perfect tonic for Aston Villa
items.summary: Aston Villa continue to surpass expectations as they bounced back from defeat by Arsenal to cement their place in the top three with an 11th straight home win. Ollie Watkins celebrated his 250th appearance for the club with his fourth goal in three games and John McGinn added two more after the interval. Villa‚Äôs ability to score out of next to nothing epitomises their season. They managed this game superbly, inflicting a fourth straight defeat on Nottingham Forest, but if the league table was made up of their expected goals difference they would have started this weekend in 15th place. Continue reading...

items.title: Nancy plunged into deeper Celtic crisis after Chermiti leads Rangers revival
items.summary: Whenever this ends ‚Äì with the answer surely ‚Äúimminently‚Äù ‚Äì Celtic‚Äôs supporters will not be the only ones to look back with outright bemusement. Wilfried Nancy‚Äôs appointment as the manager of a team who were serious operators in the Champions League a matter of months earlier will go down as one of the most bamboozling episodes in the history of Scottish football. Nancy used his Friday press conference to plead for time and context. He railed against the media, who presumably continue to err by highlighting his woeful record. By Saturday afternoon, he was wandering down the tunnel as a beaten man. Nancy‚Äôs position is untenable. He cannot be the only Celtic employee who exits, such is the scale of calamity. The simple solution for Celtic would be to call Martin O‚ÄôNeill, who presided over seven victories out of eight while in pre-Nancy caretaker charge. The 73-year-old retains capacity to revive Celtic‚Äôs fortunes. Crucially, unlike Nancy, O‚ÄôNeill has the experience and wherewithal to comprehend this unusual football environment. Continue reading...

items.title: Paul loses WBA cruiserweight ranking after defeat to Joshua
